study_abstract: The vertebrate gut microbiota evolved in an environment typified by periodic fluctuations in nutrient availability, yet little is known about its responses to host feeding and fasting. As many model species (for example, mice) are adapted to lifestyles of frequent small meals, we turned to the Burmese python, a sit-and-wait foraging snake that consumes large prey at long intervals (>1 month), to examine the effects of a dynamic nutrient milieu on the gut microbiota. We used multiplexed 16S rRNA gene pyrosequencing to characterize bacterial communities harvested from the intestines of fasted and digesting snakes, and from their rodent meal. In this unprecedented survey of a reptilian host, we found that Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes numerically dominated the python gut. In the large intestine, fasting was associated with increased abundances of the genera Bacteroides, Rikenella, Synergistes and Akkermansia, and with reduced overall diversity. A marked postprandial shift in bacterial community configuration occurred. Between 12_h and 3 days after feeding, Firmicutes, including the taxa Clostridium, Lactobacillus and Peptostreptococcaceae, gradually outnumbered the fasting-dominant Bacteroidetes, and overall ''species''-level diversity increased significantly. Most lineages seemed to be indigenous to the python rather than ingested with the meal, but a dietary source of Lactobacillus could not be ruled out. Thus, the observed large-scale alterations of the gut microbiota that accompany the Burmese python''s own dramatic physiological and morphological changes during feeding and fasting emphasize the need to consider both microbial and host cellular responses to nutrient flux. The Burmese python may provide a unique model for dissecting these interrelationships.
study_title: Postprandial remodeling of the gut microbiota in Burmese pythons

TITLE: Burmese python gut microbiome
samp_collect_device: Snakes were killed by severing the spinal cord immediately posterior to the head. Following death, a mid-ventral incision was made to expose the gastrointestinal tract, which was removed. The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake R27 from Steve Secor's lab, PSI, 0.25 days post feeding

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
reverse_primers.value: 5′-GCC TCC CTC GCG CCA TCA GNN NNN NNN NNN NCA TGC TGC CTC CCG TAG GAG T-3′

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

TITLE: Burmese python gut microbiome
samp_collect_device: Snakes were killed by severing the spinal cord immediately posterior to the head. Following death, a mid-ventral incision was made to expose the gastrointestinal tract, which was removed. The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake R8 from Steve Secor's lab, PSI, 0.25 days post feeding

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
reverse_primers.value: 5′-GCC TCC CTC GCG CCA TCA GNN NNN NNN NNN NCA TGC TGC CTC CCG TAG GAG T-3′

The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake V48 from Steve Secor's lab, Cecum, 6 days post feeding

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
reverse_primers.value: 5′-GCC TCC CTC GCG CCA TCA GNN NNN NNN NNN NCA TGC TGC CTC CCG TAG GAG T-3′

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
forward_primers.value: 5′-GCC TTG CCA GCC CGC TCA GTC AGA GTT TGA TCC TGG CTC AG-3′

TITLE: Burmese python gut microbiome
samp_collect_device: Snakes were killed by severing the spinal cord immediately posterior to the head. Following death, a mid-ventral incision was made to expose the gastrointestinal tract, which was removed. The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake S9 from Steve Secor's lab, PLI, 0.5 days post feeding

reverse_primers.value: 5′-GCC TCC CTC GCG CCA TCA GNN NNN NNN NNN NCA TGC TGC CTC CCG TAG GAG T-3′

Following death, a mid-ventral incision was made to expose the gastrointestinal tract, which was removed. The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake V43 from Steve Secor's lab, Cecum, 1 days post feeding

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
reverse_primers.value: 5′-GCC TCC CTC GCG CCA TCA GNN NNN NNN NNN NCA TGC TGC CTC CCG TAG GAG T-3′

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
forward_primers.value: 5′-GCC TTG CCA GCC CGC TCA GTC AGA GTT TGA TCC TGG CTC AG-3′

TITLE: Burmese python gut microbiome
samp_collect_device: Snakes were killed by severing the spinal cord immediately posterior to the head. Following death, a mid-ventral incision was made to expose the gastrointestinal tract, which was removed. The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake S22 from Steve Secor's lab, PLI, fasted

The contents of the cecum and the proximal and distal regions of the small and large intestines were emptied into sterile vials, immediately frozen in liquid N2 and stored at −80 ÃÂ°C. The gut content mass was determined by weighing the organ before and after emptying. In fasted snakes, the small intestine contains a small amount of clear fluid, presumably secretions from the gall bladder, pancreas and intestine. Here, several milliliters of sterile saline were used to flush the fasted small-intestinal contents into collection vials. After feeding and before day 10, the small intestine contained enough material to be squeezed directly out into vials. The large intestine typically contains some material, including residual feces, fluid and urate originating from the kidneys in fasted snakes. In the present study, material from the meal started entering the large intestine ~1-day postfeeding, with the cecum filling at 2 days. At day 3 and beyond, the large intestine and cecum were fairly filled with the material.
DESCRIPTION: Snake W20 from Steve Secor's lab, Cecum, 1 days post feeding

reverse_primers.definition: List of reverse PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
reverse_primers.value: 5′-GCC TCC CTC GCG CCA TCA GNN NNN NNN NNN NCA TGC TGC CTC CCG TAG GAG T-3′

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

reverse_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to reverse primers

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

forward_barcodes.definition: List of barcodes attached to forward primers

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

seq_center.definition: Name of instatute sequencing was done

target_gene.definition: Targeted gene or locus name for marker gene studies; e.g. 16S rRNA, 18S rRNA, nif, amoA, rpo

forward_primers.definition: List of forward PCR primers that were used to amplify the sequence of the targeted gene, locus or subfragment
forward_primers.value: 5′-GCC TTG CCA GCC CGC TCA GTC AGA GTT TGA TCC TGG CTC AG-3′

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483

elevation.definition: The elevation of the sampling site in meters as measured by the vertical distance from mean sea level.

collection_timezone.definition: The timezone of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. UTC-7

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

collection_date.definition: The date of sampling. Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 2008-01-23

country.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the country or sea name. Country or sea names should be chosen from the INSDC country list (http://insdc.org/country.html), or the GAZ ontology (http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1397)

altitude.definition: The altitude of the sample is the vertical distance in meters between Earth's surface above Sea Level and the sampled position in the air.

env_package.definition: MIGS/MIMS/MIMARKS extension for reporting of measurements and observations obtained from one or more of the environments where the sample was obtained. Use one of: air, host-associated, human-associated, human-skin, human-oral, human-gut, human-vaginal, microbial mat|biofilm, miscellaneous, plant-associated, sediment, soil, wastewater|sludge, water

feature.definition: Environmental feature level includes geographic environmental features. Examples include: harbor, cliff, or lake. EnvO terms listed under environmental feature can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00002297

longitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by longitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

location.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by the specific local region name

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample

latitude.definition: The geographical origin of the sample as defined by latitude. The value should be reported in decimal degrees and in WGS84 system

samp_size.definition: Amount or size of sample (volume, mass or area) that was collected, along with the unit used

collection_time.definition: The local time of sampling.  Use ISO8601 compliant format, ie. 19:23:10

metagenome_name.definition: Unique name for the sequences from this library

investigation_type.definition: Library construction type. This field is either metagenome for whole genome shotgun sequencing or mimarks-survey for amplicon/16S rRNA sequencing

seq_meth.definition: Sequencing method used. Use one of: Sanger, pyrosequencing, ABI-solid, 454, Illumina, assembeled, other

sample_name.definition: Unique name or id of the sample the library is derived from

biome.definition: The environmental biome represents the major classes of ecologically similar communities of plants, animals, and other organisms. Biomes are defined based on factors such as plant structures, leaf types, plant spacing, and other factors like climate. Examples include: desert, taiga, deciduous woodland, or coral reef. EnvO terms listed under environmental biome can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00000428

material.definition: The environmental material level refers to the matter that was displaced by the sample, prior to the sampling event. Environmental matter terms are generally mass nouns. Examples include: air, soil, or water. EnvO terms listed under environmental matter can be found from the link: http://bioportal.bioontology.org/visualize/1069/?conceptid=ENVO%3A00010483
